newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: INTERVIEW - Informix Asia spared corporate woes.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Informix Asia spared corporate woes.

text.p: U.S. database company Informix Corp is making money in Asia and expects regional business to remain profitable this year despite the company's overall losses, a senior official said on Thursday.
"It (Asia) is profitable," Wilson Tan, managing director of Informix Southeast Asia told Reuters in an interview.

Tan was referring to the region's first quarter performance against Informix's overall losses of US$140.1 million. The company has also said it would not return to profitability until the end of the year.

"We've had some weaknesses in Europe, some weaknesses in America. Predominantly within Asia-Pacific itself we've had some weaknesses in Japan, but anything that is outside that, we have had good growth," he said.
Countries like Thailand and Philippines had achieved revenue growth of 70-80 percent in the first quarter and was "very profitable still" but he declined to reveal profit levels.
The Southeast Asia region as a whole should see revenue grow 30-50 percent, Tan said. Profit was expected to grow at a stable rate, he added.
In 1996, the Asia Pacific region, excluding Japan, accounted for about 10 percent of Informix's global sales of US$939.3 million, he said.

Informix's problems stemmed from an over-emphasis on its leading edge product, the Universal Server launched last December. Despite praises from analysts, customers have not been quick to adopt the technology.

The Universal Server, which Informix was promoting in a roadshow in Singapore on Thursday, merges relational and object-oriented database capabilities. It can recognise linkages between data as well as track multimedia images.

It provides databases for the low-end Windows NT environment suitable for smaller business up to the very high-end MPP (massively parallel processing) environment for huge amount of different data types.

"Over the last eight to 12 months, with the emphasis on the new media-type databases, we may have been a little bit before the market and we could have kept our eyes off the ball of our core products.
"But within Asia, the impact is less significant," Tan said.

Asia was still focused on online transactions which Informix has been addressing with its traditional alpha-numeric products. With the hindsight of its U.S. and Europe experiences, Informix would keep its focus on traditional products while making known its leading edge technology, Tan said.
Driven by the Internet and emphasis on multimedia, Universal Server would become more pervasive in 1999-2000, he said.
With the new product, Informix is aiming to capture some 85 percent of data worth US$20-30 billion that are currently not digitally stored on traditional databases, Tan said.
Tan brushed aside several class action lawsuits filed by some shareholders, saying they were not uncommon when financial performance was down.
There was no concerns in Asia over whether Informix would succeed in its plans to raise capital to offset upcoming losses and shore up its shrinking cash supply, he said.
Informix plans to add new Informix superstores in Asia Pacific by the third quarter where customers can test run and build prototypes of their database applications.
Besides its main competitor, Oracle Corp, Informix has to keep a close watch on Microsoft Corp as well.
"We cannot take our eyes off Microsoft... as they make NT at some point or other scalable.

"And as Intel comes up with even more powerful chips and could replace some things like symmetric multiprocessing on the Intel platform itself, then Microsoft will become a very potent force to be reckoned with," Tan said.
-- Singapore newsroom (65-8703080)
